High-entropy oxides for catalysis: Status and perspectives Yu Gao a Yuzhi Liu a ⁎ Haiyang Yu b Donglei Zou b ⁎ a Water Research Center, Institute of Environment and Ecology, Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen, China Water Research Center, Institute of Environment and Ecology, Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University Shenzhen China Water Research Center, Institute of Environment and Ecology, Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen, China b Key Lab of Groundwater Resources and Environment, Ministry of Education, Jilin University, Changchun, China Key Lab of Groundwater Resources and Environment, Ministry of Education, Jilin University Changchun China Key Lab of Groundwater Resources and Environment, Ministry of Education, Jilin University, Changchun, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Recently, entropy stabilized catalytic systems have been raised great concerns due to the urgent demand for functional materials aiming to realize chemical catalysis. As one of the significant groups, high entropy oxides (HEOs) with variable structure, controllable chemical composition, and rich functional properties have become the research hotspots. This review briefly introduces the advantages of HEOs in the catalytic system brought by their structural characteristics and fully summarizes recent applications of HEOs in thermal/electro/photo-catalysis and supports. Finally, the future prospects of HEOs in environmental catalysis, such as visible light catalysis, catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO), and single-atom catalyst supports are proposed, which will provide a general direction for the development and breakthrough of HEOs in related fields. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords High-entropy oxides Catalysis Metal oxides Environmental catalysis 1 Introduction Environmental pollutants produced by rapid industrial development have led to serious ecological problems [1], resulting in the huge demand for efficient pollutants removal methods. Currently, the most common strategies to remove environmental pollutants are catalytic oxidation methods, such as photocatalytic [2] and electrocatalytic degradation [3], catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) [4], Fenton - like process [5]. In these processes, catalyst is the critical factor to restrict the long-term and efficient degradation of contaminants due to the deactivation of the catalyst and the dissolution of heavy metals during the reaction. Therefore, how to obtain green and stable catalyst is the most important for environmental researchers and engineers. High-entropy oxides (HEOs) that first proposed by Rost et al. [6] in 2015, are single-phase multi-component solid solutions driven by configuration entropy (S config ). Since HEO’s inception, their unique structure and chemical properties, the explorations of HEOs in thermal stability [7], magnetic properties [8], lithium-ion storage properties [9], dielectric properties [10] and catalytic properties [11] have attracted the extensive interests of researchers. Compared with the traditional doped transition metal oxides, the chemical composition and atoms distribution of HEOs are often disordered, which lead to excellent performance in thermodynamic, structural and kinetic properties [12]. For instance, Deng et al. [13] confirmed that the HEO (MoNiCuZnCoOx) not only possesses the oxidative desulfurization efficiency of physically mixed multi-metal catalysts, but also has better thermal stability. Catalyst is a significant development direction of HEOs due to their high stability and activity. The catalytic advantage of HEOs lies in the collective effect of their multi-component confined in the same lattice and the oxygen defect caused by lattice distortion [14]. By using non-traditional synthesis methods, it is easy to obtain a wide range of entropy stable multi-component systems with customized composition, structure and architectures. Moreover, the restriction of multiple different types of cations in the same lattice is achieved by enhanced S config , which enriches the number of oxygen holes in the active catalytic center [15]. In addition, the significant lattice distortion in HEOs reduces the energy of the whole system, thus promoting the activation and transport of active species. For example, the stable HEO rock salt structure provides structural support for the ability of Cu (II) / Cu (I) redox couple to improve the catalytic performance of CO oxidation [16]. Scholars have reviewed the technologies and methods of HEOs in design and synthesis [17], and summarized the applications of HEOs as energy storage and conversion materials [18], magnetic materials [8] and catalytic materials [19]. For example, Sun and Dai [20] commented the latest progress in the discovery and design of high entropy material (HEM)for catalysis, and emphasized the correlation between component and structural engineering and the optimization of catalytic behavior. They also concluded the reasonable entropy design of HEO is helpful to prepare spinel high entropy MgAl2O4 for persistent methane oxidation catalyst, and commented that the thermodynamically favorable and kinetically sluggish nature of HEO will bring revolutionary opportunities to the catalytic field [21]. Moreover, Albedwawi et al. [19] pointed out the structural elements of HEOs and discussed their great potential as promising catalysts, focusing more on the performance of HEOs in the fields of thermal, electrical and photocatalyst from the perspective of material synthesis and structure. However, the activity characteristics and performance of HEOs in the specific catalytic process have not been fully explained. Because these characteristics has significant guidance for understanding the catalytic mechanism of HEOs and subsequent industrial applications, this paper reviews recent advances in HEOs for catalysis. First of all, we briefly introduce the advantages of HEOs in the catalytic system brought by their structural characteristics. Secondly, the activity characteristics and performance of HEOs in thermal/electro/photo-catalysis and supports were analyzed, and the relationship between the characteristics of HEOs and catalytic performance was highlighted. Finally, we discuss the perspectives of HEOs in environmental catalysis such as visible light catalysis, CWAO and single-atom catalyst supports. Although these emerging and highly promising HEOs have not thrived in the field of environmental catalysis, we hope that the insights provided here can bring new vitality to environmental catalysis. 2 High-entropy oxides 2.1 Classification of high entropy materials The concept of high entropy can be traced back to two independent studies of multicomponent alloys in 2004. Yeh et al. [22] first proposed that high entropy alloy (HEAs) contain five or more major elements, with 5–35% atomic content of each central component. In the same year, Cantor et al. [23] independently reported a similar study on five-component single-phase alloys, but referred them to ‘multi-component alloys (MPEAs)’. After defining HEAs, ‘high entropy’ has entered people's vision as an independent concept with rapid development, which are considered as a breakthrough in the field of multi-component alloys. In recent years, to explore new metal structural materials with excellent properties, researchers have expanded the design concept of HEAs to high-entropy material (HEMs), including ceramics (HECs) materials. Besides, series of new ceramic materials such as HEOs [6], high entropy carbides [24], high entropy nitrides [25], high entropy borides [26], high entropy sulfides [27] and high entropy silicides [28] have also been studied, as shown in Fig. 1(a). 2.2 The concept of HEOs HEMs are a kind of materials that can reduce free energy by increasing the configuration entropy (S config ) to make the system phase-stable [14]. From the relationship between S config and number of microstates [Eqs. (1–2)] [29], the S config of materials elevates with the increase of several microstates, among which the contribution of cations to the S config is prominent, while the contribution of anions can be ignored. When the molar number of each cation in the multi-component system is equal, the system has a larger S config [Eq. (3)]. What’s more, Yeh [30] considered that S config = 1.50 R is a necessary condition to resist the strong bonding force between atoms at high temperature. Consequently, S config = 1.50 R is the boundary between high entropy and medium entropy materials. The minimum condition of high entropy (1.61 R) can be satisfied only when the number of cations are five and the molar ratio are equal, as shown in Fig. 1(b). However, when the number of cations is more than five, the different molar ratios of HEAs can also satisfy the high entropy condition [30]. Therefore, in general, the single-phase oxide solid solution is called HEO only when the type of cations contained in the solid solution is ≥ 5, and their molar ratio is equal. (1) S config =klnw (2) S config = − R ∑ i = 1 N x i ln x i cation − site + ∑ j = 1 N x j ln x j an ion − site (3) S config =RlnN Where k is the Boltzmann constant, w is the number of microstates, R is the ideal gas constant, N is the number of components, x i is the mole fraction of cation, x j is the mole fraction of anion. 2.3 Effect of crystal structure and active sites on catalysis The combination of different metal elements can form various crystalline HEOs, as shown in Fig. 1(c), for example, (Mg, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn), (Mg, Ti, Zn, Cu, Fe), and (Zr, Ce, Hf, Ti, La, Y, Gd, Ca, Mg, Mn) can form rock salt, fluorite and spinel phase HEO, respectively. This provides more choices for different catalytic reactions at the structural level due to their unique lattice distortion and tunable electronic properties [18]. Moreover, the elements Mg, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn are the five most frequently occurring metal elements for the preparation of HEOs as catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1(d). This may be attributed to the high catalytic activity of Co, Ni, and Cu, followed by the high-temperature stability of the rock salt-type HEOs formed by them [29]. In addition, the same crystal form of HEO can also show the same excellent effect in different types of catalytic reactions owing to the abundant active sites on its surface. Table 1 summarizes the structure, synthetic method, and catalytic type of different HEOs. For instance, rock salt type HEO NiMgCuZnCoOx can be synthesized in three different ways [16,31,32]. Different synthesis methods do not change their crystal structure, which reflects the excellent phase stability of HEO in the synthesis process. However, its active sites for CO oxidation, benzyl alcohol oxidation, and CO2 reduction are different, which are Cu (II)/Cu (I), oxygen vacancies and lamellar hole framework, and platinum group metals, respectively. Table 1 also summarizes the recent catalytic active sites of high entropy oxides, indicating that M (metal)-O (oxygen) bonds, oxygen vacancies and active metals are the three main catalytic active sites of HEO, as shown in Fig. 2. Firstly, M-O bonds are rich in HEO, which can not only directly participate in the catalytic reaction, but also produce abundant oxygen vacancies. For example, the introduction of Zr4+ expands the M-O bond length of FeMgCoNiOx and produces more oxygen vacancies with the increase of Zr4+, which greatly improves the thermochemical properties of FeMgCoNiOx. By adjusting the content of Zr 4+ from 0.0 to 1.0, FeMgCoNiOx / Zr0.6 was found to show the best trade-off, with an H2 yield of 4.84 mmol/g, 2 times higher than FeMgCoNiOx (2.35 mmol/g) and excellent thermodynamic energy efficiency (50%) [33]. Secondly, oxygen vacancies play a dual role in improving the thermochemical properties of metal oxides [34]. On the one hand, they are reaction center molecules for adsorbing and dissociating H2O molecules. On the other hand, oxygen vacancies can anchor the doped ions by generating additional regulatory sites and strong adsorption[35]. For instance, Gu et al. [36] verified that surface enriched oxygen vacancies can enhance the inherent activity of P-HEO. The current density normalized by electrochemically active surface area and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller at 1.50 V vs. RHE of P-HEOs is about 7-fold and 2-fold higher than that of C-HEOs. Finally, noble metals are used as the loaded metal of HEO due to their excellent catalytic performance, and then become the active center of HEO catalysis. For example, (NiMgCuCoZn)Ox, as-prepared (0.3 wt% PtNiMgCuCoZn)Ox and reduced (0.3 wt% PtNiMgCuCoZn)Ox can make CO ultimately converted, but the lowest equilibrium temperature is 305 ℃, 245 ℃, and 155 ℃, indicating that noble metals are still the principal active center of the catalyst [15]. 2.4 Effect of HEOs’ characteristics on catalysis Due to many kinds of elements and different atomic radii, HEAs have high entropy effect in thermodynamics, lattice distortion in structure, sluggish diffusion in dynamics and cocktail effect in performance [30] as shown in Fig. 3. These four effects make the HEAs have excellent comprehensive properties, such as high strength and hardness, good corrosion resistance, excellent ductility and fatigue resistance. Although HEOs did not appear when the four effects were proposed, these effects are also applicable to HEOs due to the basic characteristics of HEOs and HEAs are similar and multi-principal materials [29]. Firstly, the high entropy effect is the most fundamental. High S config can increase the compatibility between the principal components and reduce the total free energy, thus avoiding the formation of terminal solid solution or intermetallic compounds due to phase separation to the greatest extent. It is the decisive factor for the phase stability of multicomponent systems at high temperature. However, the performance of traditional multicomponent systems is mainly determined by one or two main elements, resulting in the S config of them being generally below 1 R which is far less than 1.5 R of the entropy limit of HEOs. Hence, the phase stability of traditional low-entropy oxides is not as splendid as that of HEOs. For example, in the process of catalytic desulfurization, although physically mixed catalysts can also achieve the same catalytic performance as MoNiCuZnCoOx − 900 at the beginning, their stability is far less than that of MoNiCuZnCoOx − 900 [13]. Secondly, the HEMs of lattice distortion caused by limiting multiple main elements to the same lattice is attractive for the design of phase-stable catalysts with high activity and specific selectivity. The existence of lattice distortion in HEMs is attributed to different element sizes. Since each metal in the HEMs has the same probability of occupying the lattice position, big atomic size will lead to too high lattice distortion energy, which can produce severe lattice distortion and even cause lattice collapse to form an amorphous structure. The mechanical, electrical, thermal, optical and chemical behaviors of materials can be changed by the lattice distortion effect [14]. For instance, Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2Mg0.2Zn0.2O possesses more excellent performance to catalyze the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid due to the oxygen vacancy caused by lattice distortion [31]. Thirdly, the different diffusion rates of different types of atoms in HEMs, the change of chemical bonds and the divergence of potential energy cause the lower diffusion rate of atoms in HEMs than in traditional metallic materials. The high diffusion activation energy of HEMs leads to sluggish diffusion kinetics, which is considered the main driving force for enhancing chemical, thermal and mechanical stability [14]. For example, the order of diffusion properties in each alloy is low entropy alloy > medium entropy alloy > high entropy alloy. The high-temperature strength and phase stability of HEMs and the generation of nanocrystals in HEMs surface are all due to the sluggish diffusion effect [30]. Finally, the cocktail effect first proposed by Ranganatha [37] emphasizes that the performances of multi-component alloys are affected by the properties of primary elements. The HEMs have more principal components (N ≥ 5), and the properties of each principal component and the interaction between atoms make the material present a complex cocktail effect. This makes HEMs be provided with excellent characteristics of their main elements, such as high catalytic activity, temperature thermal stability, strength and corrosion resistance, and become a strong competitor of catalysts and supports. For example, TiZrHfNbTaO11 exhibits better light absorbance in the visible light region (bandgap of 2.9 eV) than its cations oxides such as TiO2, ZrO2, HfO2, Nb2O5, and Ta2O5 (bandgap of 3.1–5.7 eV) [38]. 3 Catalysis and supports Almost all noble metals can be used as catalysts, especially Platinum and Rhodium. The unfilled d-electron orbitals enable them to form coordination bonds to participate in the reaction. Moreover, it is not easy for them to attach reactants and reaction products to the surface, so that the active sites remain active all the time [39]. At the same time, noble metals have excellent properties such as oxidation and corrosion resistance, which make them the main catalyst metals [40]. However, noble metals are rare in nature. In fact, the content of Platinum and Palladium in the earth's crust are five and one parts per billion separately, which makes noble metal catalysts expensive. Due to the low Tammann temperature, noble metal catalysts are easy to lose catalytic activity under harsh reaction conditions [41]. Therefore, transition elements as the HEOs catalytic core have also been revisited to discuss on thermal stability by high entropy drive. HEOs have advantages in high temperature stability and activity stability due to their unique characteristics such as high entropy, lattice distortion, sluggish diffusion and cocktail effect. Table 2 presents a summary of the research progress of HEOs in catalyst and supports in recent years. Researchers have made many outstanding innovative achievements in catalysts and supports. This section describes the application of HEO in the field of catalysis, especially their superior performance in thermal/electro/photo-catalysis and supports. 3.1 Thermal catalysis 3.1.1 CO oxidation Low-temperature CO oxidation is one of the most widely studied catalytic oxidation reactions in the history of heterogeneous catalysis due to its importance in purifying the air and reducing vehicle emissions [42]. Transition metals (such as Mn, Co, Cu and Ni) and noble metals (such as Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Pt and Au) are widely used in CO oxidation. However, it is still a great challenge to develop active and stable catalysts without or trace noble metals for CO oxidation at low temperatures [14]. HEOs are single-phase oxides existing in various transition metals with high oxidation states, which makes them suitable catalysts or cocatalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation. Riley et al. [43] reported a class of fluorite structure HEOs without noble metal -Ce (Al, Fe, La, Mn, Nd, Pr, Sm, Y, Zr) O, which are used to catalyze CO oxidation. When using Ce0.8(LaMnNdZr)0.2O2−y as catalysis, the dosage is 20 mg, and the CO flow rate is 1.5 mL/min, the CO conversion rate can reach 100% at 300 ℃. Compared with pure ceria and conventional HEO, Ce (Al, Fe, La, Mn, Nd, Pr, Sm, Y, Zr) O have the larger specific surface area and better catalytic activity due to their tunable oxygen storage capacity. They confirmed that the first row of transition metal cations is the most effective to improve the activity of CO oxidation. However, their addition reduces the thermal stability of CO oxidation. Rare earth cations such as Ce were necessary to prevent thermal deactivation while maintaining activity. Unfortunately, the stability of the catalyst has not been tested, and its further application needs to be developed. Chen et al. [32] developed an entropy-driven mechanochemical process to fabricate heterostructure CuCeOx-NiMgCuZnCoOx. They compared the CO catalytic oxidation efficiency of CeO2, NiMgCuZnCoOx, and CuCeOx-NiMgCuZnCoOx, indicating that CuCeOx-(NiMgCuZnCo)O (Cu molar ratio of 20 mol%) exhibited the highest conversion efficiency (100%) of CO at 200 °C. Due to the increase of entropy in the short-range high-temperature process of ball milling of NiMgCuZnCoOx and CeO2, some of the less stable CuO and ZnO migrated from the HEO solid solution into the CeO2 lattice, thus forming heterostructure CuCeOx-NiMgCuZnCoOx. It shows excellent high-temperature stability, and almost no active degradation after calcination at 900 ℃, as shown in Fig. 4(a). For CuO-CeO2, high temperature (900 ℃) destroys the active sites of CeCuOx and further leads to the decrease of catalytic activity, which demonstrates the key role of entropy induced reconstruction of oxide interface structure. Fracchia et al. [16] prepared a kind of rock salt type HEOs (Mg0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2Zn0.2O) to study the mechanism of catalytic oxidation of CO by using operando soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy. The results showed that Cu in HEO catalyzes the oxidation of CO. CO can quickly reduce Cu (II) to Cu (I) when the temperature was higher than 130 °C. At the same time, the high configuration entropy stable rock salt structure permitted the oxidation/reduction of Cu to be reversible, thus ensuring the catalytic reaction of CO to occur cyclically, while CO and Ni do not contribute to the catalysis. 3.1.2 Desulfurization Desulfurization process is a fundamental way to eliminate sulfur species in fossil fuels and relieve major environmental problems caused by corrosive and toxic sulfoxide (SOx) generated from the combustion of sulfur compounds in fossil fuels. Deng et al. [13] reported an entropy stable single-phase solid solution HEOs (MoNiCuZnCoOx) as a catalyst for oxidative desulfurization of fuel, which showed excellent catalytic activity even when calcined at 900 ℃. Compared with traditional metal oxides, high entropy structure introduces more defects in HEOs, which usually act as active catalytic centers. Firstly, the desulfurization efficiency of MoCo, NiCuZn, physical mixture, and MoNiCuZnCoOx-900 (HEO-900) catalysts under the same conditions was compared. The results show that the prepared HEO-900 at 900 ℃ has the best catalytic performance. The formation of solid solution is beneficial to the uniform dispersion and stabilization of Mo, which improves the oxidative desulfurization activity. Although physically mixed catalysts can also achieve the same catalytic performance as HEO-900, their reusability is far less than that of HEO-900. In addition, HEO-900 was compared with other researchers' catalysts such as MIL-101(Cr) [44], H5PV2Mo10O40/SiO2 [45], CNT-SZ [46], Cu NPs/ g-BN [47], HEO-900 can shorten the desulfurization time to 3 h, which is faster than most previous aerobic oxidation desulfurization systems. 3.1.3 Hydrocarbons and their derivatives oxidation Compared with traditional flame combustion, catalytic combustion of methane (CH4) can stabilize the complete oxidation of fuel at low temperatures and reduce emissions (such as NOx). Therefore, the conversion and utilization of CH4 have been a research hotspot for many years. Li et al. [48] synthesized and stabilized single-phase HEO nanoparticles containing ten cations (including one noble element) for CH4 oxidation by adjusting temperature, oxidation and entropy-driven mixing. Firstly, the better catalyst (Zr, Ce)0.6Mg0.3Pd0.1Ox composed of 4-elements (100% conversion at ~ 540 ℃) was selected by comparing with PdOx (74% conversion at ~ 540 ℃). Then, after (Zr, Ce)0.6Mg0.3Pd0.1Ox was selected, a series of 5-element HEOs (Zr, Ce)0.6(Z)Mg0.3Pd0.1Ox were constructed by adding eight different 3d-5d transition metals (Z = La, Y, Hf, Ti, Cr, Mn, Fe and Cu) into (Zr, Ce)0.6Mg0.3Pd0.1Ox. When Z = La, Y, Hf, Ti, Cr or Mn, the performance of 5-element HEOs is better than that of 4-elements (Zr, Ce)0.6Mg0.3Pd0.1Ox, while the addition of Fe and Cu has a poison effect. Finally, by combining the six elements identified from the second screening step (La, Y, Hf, Ti, Cr and Mn) with the best performing elements, 10-element HEOs were synthesized. Compared with other catalysts (single PdOx, 4-elements (Zr, Ce)0.6Mg0.3Pd0.1Ox and 5-element HEOs), 10-element HEOs showed higher catalytic activity and achieved complete conversion at ~ 127 ℃. In addition, 10-element HEOs showed stable performance in both low and high gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) for 100 h continuous operation, demonstrating the intrinsic stability of the catalyst. Nie et al. [49] prepared porous spinel HEO (HE-MgAl2O4) (up to denary metals: Mg, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) to catalyze CO and C3H6 oxidation, and tested the stability of HE-MgAl2O4 by continuous oxidation of CH4. Compared with single spinel MgAl2O4 and CuAl2O4, HE-MgAl2O4 showed better catalytic performance for CO or C3H6 oxidation. In addition, the apparent activation energies (Ea) of them were measured and calculated: MgAl2O4 (Ea = 103.88 kJ / mol) > CuAl2O4 (Ea = 61.75 kJ / mol) > 10- HE-MgAl2O4 (Ea = 41.03 kJ / mol) > 5- HE-MgAl2O4 (Ea = 37.95 kJ / mol). This further proves that HE-MgAl2O4 has excellent catalytic performance compared with single spinel. In order to study the stability of these catalysts, CH4 oxidation experiments were carried out at 600 ℃ and in the feed gas of 10 vol% steam. No significant reduction of CH4 conversion was observed in the HE-MgAl2O4 catalyst group within 100 h which was due to the thermal stability caused by the entropy stability and kinetic stability of HE-MgAl2O4. However, the moisture in the feed gas shows a destructive effect on MgAl2O4 and CuAl2O4, and the CH4 conversion decreases after 50 h. Benzaldehyde, benzoic acid and benzyl benzoate are valuable intermediates and raw materials in industrial production. The development of the non-noble metal multiphase catalyst has a broad application prospect for selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols to benzaldehyde, benzoic acid and benzyl benzoate. Using graphene oxide as the sacrificial template, Feng et al. [31] firstly designed and synthesized porous lamellar HEO(Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2Mg0.2Zn0.2O) with mesoporous structure, which was used to catalyze the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid. Compared with Au / Pd-TiO2 catalyst (conversion rate = 91.6% in 8 h under 0.2 MPa) [50], HEO catalyst can not only run at atmospheric pressure, but also reach the equilibrium of catalytic reaction in a shorter time (2 h), and the conversion can reach 98%. After five cycles, the selectivity and conversion of the catalyst are almost the same as that of the fresh catalyst, indicating the catalyst is highly stable in the catalytic environment. The salient catalytic activity originates from the existence of the increased oxygen vacancies sites in the unique structure of random distribution of elements on the atomic scale duo to lattice distortion characteristics of HEOs. The porous lamellar structure composed of HEO (specific surface area (~ 42 m2/g) and pore volume of 0.106 cm3/g) dramatically increases the surface exposure of the catalyst, which significantly improves the adsorption capacity of the HEO for benzyl alcohol. Various metal ions exposed on the surface of HEO increase the active sites of HEO, and lattice defects make HEO rich in oxygen vacancies, which enhance the bonding of hydrogen and M-O bonds between alcohol molecular functional groups (- OH) and oxygen atoms on the exposed surface, and then promote the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid. 3.1.4 Production of carbon nanotubes Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have rich and excellent properties due to their unique geometry and electronic structure, leading to a broad application prospect in the fields of industrial additives and electronics devices. Pyrolysis catalysis is the most feasible and straightforward way to grow high yield carbon nanotubes in many technologies, such as CNTs discharge, laser ablation and hydrothermal method [51]. Lal et al. [52] reported a radical strategy to use HEO nanoparticles as catalysts for the growth of high yield CNTs, resulting in HEO - CNT nanocomposites with sizeable specific surface (151 m2/g) area and high mechanical strength for energy applications such as electrochemical capacitors. In HEO - CNT, catalyst nanoparticles are encapsulated and uniformly diffused to the whole surface structure, which enhances the thermal, mechanical, structural stability and electrochemical activity of CNTs. Full-cell electrochemical capacitors nanocomposites based on HEO - CNT have a high capacitance of 71.0 F g−1 in PVA / H2SO4 electrolyte and 271.0 F g−1 in [BMIM] [TFSI] electrolyte at the current density of 1 A g −1, which exhibits a 100% capacitance retention and a coulombic efficiency up to 15, 000 cycles. Compared with other electrode materials such as SWNT [53] and PANI [54], it has better energy (~ 217 W h kg−1) and power density (2396.3 W h kg−1) with a wide potential window of 2.5 V. 3.2 Electrocatalysis 3.2.1 Lithium-sulfur batteries With the increasing demand for environmentally friendly electric vehicles and portable electronic devices, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered as potential candidates for the next-generation of rechargeable batteries because of their advantages, including high nominal capacity of 1675 mA h g−1 and 2500 kW kg−1, high energy storage density, low price, high safety and abundant sulfur resources [55–59]. However, some of their disadvantages include complex multi-electron conversion and sulfur insulation, as well as the insulation and shuttle effect of lithium polysulfide, which leads to the reduction of battery cycle capacity and coulomb efficiency [60]. In order to solve these problems, adding catalyst to cathode to improve this situation has become a space for exploration [61,62]. For example, mesoporous carbon [63] and carbon nanotubes [64] are common host materials in cathodes, which are used to encapsulate sulfur in their porous networks to encapsulate sulfur and limit polysulfides. However, due to the physical interaction with lithium polysulfide and volume expansion during discharge, they can only partially limit polysulfides [65]. Therefore, it is necessary to design catalysts that contribute to the efficiency and characteristics of Li-S batteries. Zheng et al. [59] proposed the strategy of using NiMgCuZnCoOx and carbon as anchors in Li-S batteries to catalyze redox reactions in the cathode and limit the shuttle of polysulfides. The distribution of various cations in HEO not only provides active sites, but also limits the polysulfides in the process of charge and discharge. Among them, a variety of metal active species uniformly dispersed in HEO are conducive to the redox reaction of Li-S battery cathode. The synergy of Li-O and S-Ni bonds produced by the interaction between HEO and lithium polysulfide effectively alleviates the shuttle of lithium polysulfide between anode and cathode. At the same time, HEO shows excellent reversible capacity, good cycle stability and low-capacity attenuation of 0.077% per cycle after 600 cycles. 3.2.2 Water decomposition Electric-driven water decomposition (hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER)) and rechargeable metal-air battery are two major applications in the field of energy storage [66]. However, the kinetics of OER is sluggish, even under the promotion of relatively high activity catalysts containing noble metals. This limitation imposes considerable overpotential requirements, similar to those for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cell applications [67]. Designing cost-effective and highly active catalysts for energy storage applications is a crucial factor in the pursuit of sustainable energy. (CoCuFeMnNi)3O4 is a spine-type HEO electrocatalyst which was used for OER after being supported by multi-walled carbon nanotubes [68]. Compared with the unsupported HEO, the catalyst showed better performance in conductivity, tunable mass transfer between electrolyte and electrode (~10 mA cm−2 at 1.58 V in 1 M KOH) (Rp of 0.74 Ω and Rs of 21.67 Ω). Since then, Wang et al. [36] also reported a low-temperature O2 plasma strategy to prepare HEOs nanosheets with high specific surface area and rich defects, which will be used for the electrocatalytic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). The results show that five-membered (FeCrCoNiCu)3O4 HEOs nanosheets have lower initial reaction potential and faster reaction kinetics in electrocatalytic oxidation of HMF due to their nanosheet structure, abundant oxygen vacancies and high specific surface area (48.6 m3 g−1), which is superior to HEOs prepared by high-temperature method. The OER initial potential of P-HEOs was 1.50 V. After introducing HMF, P-HEOs electrode showed a stronger current response, and the initial potential decreased to 1.35 V, which was much lower than that of the C-HEOs electrode, which showed that P-HEOs have good electrocatalytic activity. Zhang et al. [69] prepared a spinel-phase heterojunction film (Fe0.73Cr0.71Co0.78Ni0.81Al0.1) O4.01 HEO to catalyze OER without noble metals using direct current reactive magnetron sputtering, which has an overpotential of 381 mV and long-term electrolytic stability of 120 h in alkaline solution at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The structure of HEO films depends on the oxygen flow rate in the process of preparation. The low oxygen flow rate (< 70%) is in face-centered cubic phase of solid solution, while the high oxygen flow rate (> 80%) is in spinel solid solution structure. After thermal annealing at 500–700 ℃, NiCo alloy precipitates appear on the surface of the alloy in a vacuum. The discovery of noble metal-free HEO with catalytic activity and electrochemical stability opens up a new application field of HEO. Ding et al. prepared a 2D HEO FeNiCoMnVOx which can be adjusted by plasma through the strategy of combining density functional theory (DFT) with general synthesis for electrocatalytic HER. The synergistic effect of five metal active sites and the regulation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface driven by Ar plasma lay a theoretical foundation for efficient catalytic HER. The catalyst exhibits excellent electrocatalytic HER activity with a small overpotential of 81 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm− 2 and a Tafel slope of 88 mV dec− 1. It can stably operate at 10 mA cm− 2 up to 100 h with negligible activity decay. This work creatively puts forward the strategy that the design of high entropy oxides can be predicted from theory to practical application, which provides a momentous reference for the design of high-performance HEO catalysts. 3.3 Photocatalysis 3.3.1 CO2 conversion and HER Due to the high entropy effect and lattice distortion effect, the appropriate selection of cationic elements such as Ti, Zr, Hf, Nb, Ta, Gd, La and Ce can narrow the bandgap and adjust the band structure of the HEOs, which improve their light absorption activity, making them have the ability to act as a photocatalyst. Edalati et al. [38] reported an HEO TiZrHfNbTaO11 containing 60 mol% monoclinic perovskite and 40 mol% orthorhombic perovskite using high-pressure torsion (HPT) method. They tested for the photocatalytic hydrogen production (11 μmol) by exposing it for 180 min to UV light. TiZrHfNbTaO11 exhibits good light absorbance in the visible light region with a main bandgap of 2.9 eV, while its cations oxides have bandgaps in the range of 3.1–5.7 eV with negligible light absorbance in the visible-light region. At the same time, Akrami et al. [70] studied the photocatalytic CO2 conversion of TiZrHfNbTaO11. Without the addition of CO catalyst, HEO shows the activity of simultaneously catalyzing the conversion of CO2 to CO and H2O to H2 due to the appropriate electron band structure, sterling carrier lifetime and the biphasic structure of defects and strains. The CO2 conversion photocatalytic activity of the HEO is better than that of traditional photocatalysts such as anatase TiO2 and BiVO4, which is similar to P25 TiO2. These studies confirmed the great potential of TiZrHfNbTaO11 as a novel family of photocatalysts for the conversion of CO2 and H2O. 3.3.2 Removal of pollutants Dye and heavy metal (such as Cr (VI)) wastewater are two kinds of pollution sources that seriously endanger the water environment and human health, which have been widely concerned and studied in the field of environment protection. As the first application of HEO in the water environmental protection field, Anandkumar et al. [71] prepared single-phase HEOs Gd0.2La0.2Ce0.2Hf0.2Zr0.2O2 and Gd0.2La0.2Y0.2Hf0.2Zr0.2O2 with the bandgap narrowing (2.52 eV) and (3.09 eV), respectively. These HEOs were as photocatalysts to completely remove Cr (VI) to Cr (III) in 100 min and degrade the 70% of methyl blue dye in 180 min. Compared with other emerging photocatalysts such as α-Fe2O3/g-C3N4 [72], MOF-rGO [73] and CZnO-dots [74], HEOs have the advantages of less catalyst dosage (0.5 mg mL−1) and faster (in 100 min) removal efficiency of Cr (VI) with higher concentration (100 ppm). Due to abundant oxygen defects and a narrower band gap, the obtained HEO shows an absorption shift to the visible band, which further enhances the photoreduction of Cr (VI). 3.4 Supports As catalyst supports, HEOs have the advantage of activating lattice oxygen through the compensation enthalpy gain provided by enhanced S config , and have the function of anchoring noble metal species as its active center. High entropy effect, and asymmetric distribution of atoms caused by lattice defects and sluggish diffusion of atoms reduce the energy barrier of molecular adsorption, activation and transformation, which makes HEOs have distinguished chemical and thermal stability at high temperatures [14], and makes HEOs attractive candidates for catalyst support. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted extensive attention in the field of catalysis. However, it is difficult to prepare stable monatomic catalysts on traditional supports (N-doped carbon, metal oxides, etc.), especially at high temperatures [75]. Xu et al. [15] reported an entropy-driven strategy to stabilize Pd atoms on fluorite (CeZrHfTiLa)Ox (HEFO) supports to catalyze CO oxidation by a combination of mechanical milling with calcination at 900 °C, as shown in Fig. 4(b). Due to the high entropy property of HEFO, the single Pd atoms are incorporated into HEFO sublattice by forming a stable Pd-O-M bond (M = Ce / Zr / La), while CeO2 as an alternative support cannot complete the above process, as shown in Fig. 3(a). Compared with the traditional supported catalyst (~ 253–285 ℃), the catalyst not only showed higher activity for CO oxidation at low temperature (170 ℃), but also had strong stability (the performance did not decrease significantly after seven cycles). It also has stable catalytic oxidation efficiency for C3H6 (~ 89%) and NO (~ 20%). Chen et al. [11,76] synthesized a rock salt-type HEOs-NiMgCuZnCox for the catalytic oxidation of CO and the catalytic hydrogenation of atmospheric CO2 to CO. This material can act excellent support to stabilize highly dispersed and single atomically dispersed Au, Pd and Ru species, even at temperatures up to 900 ℃. The use of Au, Pd, Ru, Ni, Mg, Cu, Zn and Co results in a high dispersion of active sites, giving high catalytic activity in CO oxidation or CO2 reduction, but noble metals are still the core of the catalysts [76]. For example, (NiMgCuCoZn)Ox, as-prepared (0.3 wt% PtNiMgCuCoZn)Ox and reduced (0.3 wt% PtNiMgCuCoZn)Ox can make CO ultimately converted, but the lowest equilibrium temperature is 305 ℃, 245 ℃, and 155 ℃, indicating that the catalytic performance of HEOs with noble metals is better than that without noble metals. What’s more, Okejiri et al. [77] found that BaSrBi(ZrHfTiFe)O3 has almost no catalytic activity, and Ru/BaSrBi(ZrHfTiFe)O3 can completely catalyze the conversion of CO at the same temperature (118 ℃). In addition, the catalyst can still maintain high thermal stability under severe conditions due to the entropy stabilization behavior in HEOs. The catalyst can be reused for at least 40 h without reducing its catalytic activity. Jin et al. [78] reported that highly dispersed Pt, Pd, Cu, Ag or Au alloy clusters (diameter ~ 1.5 nm) supported on nano porous spinel HEO (AlCoFeMoCr)3O4 were prepared by a general dealloying process and used as bifunctional OER/ORR catalysts in metal-air batteries. After doping with shallow Pt content (~ 4 wt%), AlCoFeMoCr/Pt has excellent OER performance, which is far superior to commercial IrO2 and its high entropy alloy without Pt doping. Moreover, AlCoFeMoCr/Pt composite has better ORR activity than Pt / C, and the half-wave potential shifts about 30 mV. The mass activity of Pt was 0.81 A mg−1, indicating that HEO could enhance the support of modified Pt. Interestingly, it was found that the addition of Pt clusters significantly improved the OER activity of HEO supports, and HEO supports also improved the ORR activity / durability of Pt. This work provides a new way for the design and preparation of multifunctional catalysts with adjustable composition and performance. 4 Perspectives in environmental catalysis 4.1 Visible light photocatalysis Compared with other semiconductors (such as ZrO2, ZnO, WO3, CdS, etc.), TiO2 emerges excellent ability to degrade many kinds of environmental pollutants under light radiation due to the absolute advantages of low price, non-toxic, high activity and high stability [79,80]. However, the application of TiO2 photocatalysis technology is still in the stage of laboratory research and pilot exploration, mainly because of its low utilization rate of light energy and high recombination rate of photo-generated carriers [81]. For example, only when the most commonly used anatase phase of TiO2 is irradiated by ultraviolet light with a wavelength lower than 387.5 nm, the electrons in the valence band can be excited to produce photogenerated electrons and holes [82]. However, in the natural sunlight, the energy of ultraviolet light (< 380 nm) only accounts for about 3% of the total light energy received by the earth, and most of the energy comes from visible light (45%) and infrared light (52%). Therefore, for natural light, most of the energy cannot be absorbed by anatase, resulting in its low utilization rate of light energy. The present research shows that HEOs can improve the utilization rate of light energy, especially in the visible light range. For example, Edalati et al. [38] reported TiZrHfNbTaO11 oxide exhibits good light absorbance in the visible light region compared to TiO2 with negligible light absorbance in the visible light region. Due to the multi-component and collective characteristics, HEO is more excellent in light absorption compared with its binary oxides in the Ti - Zr - Hf - Nb - Ta - O system, as shown in Fig. 3(b). Moreover, metal nitrogen oxides have become promising photocatalysts because of their narrow bandgap, but their low stability is a disadvantage compared with metal oxides [83]. Edalati et al. [84] also developed a high entropy nitrogen oxide (TiZrHfNbTaO6N3) that can be used for photocatalytic water decomposition to solve this problem. The material is an indirect semiconductor with a bandgap of 1.6 eV, which is much smaller than that of the corresponding HEO - TiZrHfNbTaO11 (2.9 eV). At the same time, compared with TiZrHfNbTaO11, TiZrHfNbTaO6N3 can absorb a large amount of light in both ultraviolet and visible regions ( Fig. 5(a)). Therefore, the high stability of the material in photocurrent generation and photocatalytic hydrogen production shows that high entropy nitrogen oxide is a promising low bandgap and stable visible light catalyst. 4.2 Catalytic wet air oxidation Catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) is an advanced oxidation technology, which can be used to treat high concentration and refractory sewage and sludge [4,85]. At present, the CWAO catalysts used in the environmental field mainly include homogeneous (copper-based and iron-based such as CuSO4 and FeSO4) and heterogeneous (such as noble metal and non-noble metal) catalysts [86], as shown in Fig. 5(b). Although the homogeneous catalyst has higher activity than the heterogeneous catalyst, they are rarely used in CWAO engineering applications because of their biological toxicity and difficulty in recycling from complex wastewater. Moreover, due to the high price and one-time investment cost and deactivation at high temperatures of noble metals, their wide application in the CWAO industry is limited. Non-noble metal (such as Fe, Cu and Ce) heterogeneous catalysts have shown an excellent catalytic performance in CWAO for treating a variety of industrial wastewater and sludge, but the biggest drawback is the severe dissolution of the active components of the catalyst, which will cause the loss of active site, decrease its activity and reuse life [87]. Therefore, it is urgent to search for efficient and stable CWAO catalyst and preparation process. Due to its unique high entropy, lattice distortion, sluggish diffusion and cocktail effect, HEO has high thermal stability, excellent catalytic performance and unique magnetic properties [14]. The main elements and their chemical composition tend to be disordered in HEOs, which leads to different performance from traditional doped oxides. In addition, due to the precise control of S config , it is easier to form simple rock-salt type, fluorite type, spinel type or perovskite solid solution structure than the traditional heterogeneous catalyst, which makes the active components of the catalyst stable and dramatically extends the service life of the catalyst [29]. Given the excellent characteristics of HEO, it is feasible to develop HEO with high activity and high stability as a CWAO catalyst. At present, most of the elements used in the synthesis of HEO are transition metal elements and rare earth elements in the fourth cycle, and a large number of elements need to be developed and applied by scholars. HEOs have high activity and stability at high temperatures due to the high entropy and sluggish diffusion effect compared with the traditional CWAO catalyst, which makes it have a broad development prospect in the field of CWAO in the future. 4.3 Single-atom catalyst supports In the development of catalytic science, the high activity of catalyst is obtained by continuously reducing the size of active metal particles and improving the utilization of metal atoms (Fig. 5(c)) [88]. Theoretically, when the limit size of the active component of the catalyst is a single atom, the atomic utilization rate of the active component is 100%. However, the atomic utilization of traditional bulk, nano and sub nano catalysts is far lower than this ideal level [89]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) show high catalytic activity in catalytic reactions due to their unsaturated coordination environment, high atomic utilization, unique metal-support interaction and clear active centers [90,91]. At the same time, its single active site can significantly improve the catalytic selectivity and avoid side reactions [92]. However, the high surface energy of SACs makes it easy to aggregate and form large metal particles in the process of preparation and application, which makes it challenging to improve the metal loading in SACs [93]. Recently, as a new type of metal oxide, HEOs are widely considered to be an excellent support for SACs because of their unique high entropy, lattice distortion, sluggish diffusion and cocktail effect. HEO stabilized SACs can provide low-temperature catalytic oxidation activity and significant durability even under harsh conditions. For example, Xu et al. [15] prepared and synthesized anti sintering Pd SACs stabilized on HEO under mechanochemical conditions, as shown in Fig. 4(b). The catalyst not only has excellent CO oxidation activity, but also has excellent resistance to thermal degradation and aggregation. Due to the high entropy and lattice distortion of HEO, a single Pd atom is incorporated into the HEO sublattice by forming a stable Pd - O - M bond (M = Ce / Zr / La), and the above process cannot be completed with other metal oxides as alternative carriers. However, HEO is easy to harden during sintering, resulting in the reduction of monatomic metal anchoring defect sites. Zhao et al. [94] proposed a sol-gel-assisted mechanical lapping strategy to effectively inhibit the growth of HEO particles by adding Al2O3, leading to more surface defects in HEO, as shown in Fig. 5(d). The designed continuous interface effectively inhibits the further growth of HEO particles. Nanoscale γ-Al2O3 can prevent the agglomeration of HEO nanoparticles and produce more oxygen vacancies on HEO, which is conducive to the high dispersion (Pt-O-M bond) of Pt species on HEO surface during calcination, as shown in Fig. 5(e). HEO has shown its material advantages in the field of single-atom catalyst support. The high entropy property of HEO can provide more reliable phase stability for SACs than traditional oxide supports. Secondly, oxygen vacancies caused by lattice distortion of HEO can effectively load more single atoms, which improves the single-atom load. Moreover, the sluggish diffusion effect of HEO will slow down the agglomeration of loaded single atoms, and then effectively maintain the catalytic activity of single atom catalyst. Therefore, an appropriate strategy for the design of loaded single atoms on HEO is the focus of future research. It is worth looking forward to that the reasonable design of HEO-supported single-atom catalyst may open a new door for stabilizing SACs. 5 Conclusion As a new disordered entropy stable catalyst, high entropy oxides (HEOs) have higher structural stability and better physical and chemical properties than traditional catalysts due to their characteristics mainly reflected in high entropy, lattice distortion, sluggish diffusion and cocktail effect. Although HEO has been tried and developed in thermal/electro/photo -catalysis and supports, it is still in the initial stage of laboratory research and development. The unique physical and chemical properties make HEOs an excellent choice for environmental catalysts such as visible light, CWAO catalysts and single-atom catalyst supports. Developing HEOs as environmental catalysts and revealing the mechanism of entropy stability and lattice distortion in the catalytic process are significant development directions in the future. coredata.dc:description: Recently, entropy stabilized catalytic systems have been raised great concerns due to the urgent demand for functional materials aiming to realize chemical catalysis. As one of the significant groups, high entropy oxides (HEOs) with variable structure, controllable chemical composition, and rich functional properties have become the research hotspots. This review briefly introduces the advantages of HEOs in the catalytic system brought by their structural characteristics and fully summarizes recent applications of HEOs in thermal/electro/photo-catalysis and supports. Finally, the future prospects of HEOs in environmental catalysis, such as visible light catalysis, catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO), and single-atom catalyst supports are proposed, which will provide a general direction for the development and breakthrough of HEOs in related fields.
coredata.dc:title: High-entropy oxides for catalysis: Status and perspectives
